primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God breaks the closed system of human reason and control by bringing life out of death (Isaac's birth) to establish a future based on promise rather than human fabrication.

tekstueel_bewijs: God has more faith, more resilience, more confidence
God... gives life to the dead and calls into existence the things that do not exist
God works a genuine new possibility
this yearned-for, unexpected, desperately wanted baby
newness, things that do not yet exist
The God who makes promises and keeps them
Abraham and Sarah and all of us
Paul and the whole church are custodians
The dance of faith that does not ask for explanation
our tightly disciplined, fearfully guarded notion of what is possible
Holding on grimly is an act of atheism
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a bad habit but a fundamental 'atheism' that denies God's creative power.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of relinquishment and cross-bearing in light of God's newness.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The 'demanding' nature of the miracle is a consequence of the gift already given.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: Lyrical Imagination → God ← Human Control ('Yes, but')

voorbeelden_god_subject: God... calls into existence the things that do not exist
God intends us no conventional life
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We can name it and we cling to it

voorbeelden: I must die, I must be crucified
let them... take up their cross
We do not want to turn loose
Israel comes to know everything that needs to be known
God was able to do what God had promised
the impossible power of God has overcome

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon centers on God's 'Pouvoir' (Power/Ability) vs. Human 'Incapacité' (Inability). Grace is defined as God's capacity to act where humans cannot.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Dead bodies/Closed world) through ~S1 (Yes, but/Control) to S1 (Isaac/Newness).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: God's speech act ('calls into existence') creates a new reality that bypasses the logic of the closed system.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; death and 'atheistic' control are presented as the default human state.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It explicitly denies human 'creation' and places the agency of new life entirely in God's hands.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: He is also an invitation to believe and trust and risk and relinquish.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: the Bible never uses the word create with a human subject... only God creates.
Biblical faith is grounded in God’s capacity to keep promises.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Abraham is used as a model of faith, but only after the sermon establishes that the miracle was 'not of normal human circumstance' but of God.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides this: Abraham is the 'Receiver' of a gift he could not 'fabricate'.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of control; invitation to wonder.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic start (God acts) leading to a responsive discipleship.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'gift' (Isaac) to the 'demand' (Cross) is handled as a narrative necessity—the gift is so big it displaces the old self.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'unconditional gift' and 'demanding discipleship'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the impossible power of God has overcome our tightly disciplined... notion of what is possible.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon speaks of 'God's power' generally rather than the specific person of the Spirit.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is seen as 'atheism' and the 'fearful need to control'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is driven by God as Subject. The 'Yes, but' functions as a formidable Opponent that only a 'Miracle' (Object) can overcome.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might feel they must 'generate' the imagination themselves.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Receiver of the 'Lyrical Imagination' as a gift.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the 'Can you imagine?' is also a gift from the Sender, not a human work.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain, but clarify the source of the 'Vouloir' (Willing) in the second half.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Link the 'relinquishment' more explicitly to the Spirit's work.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: The current structure (Gift → Demand) is correct.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in maintaining God as the Subject of the narrative while still addressing the radical cost of discipleship.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Yes, but' / 'Can you imagine' antithesis; Greimas shows this is a conflict between two different Actantial Senders (Reason vs. Promise).
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the text; Greimas shows how the sermon's 'engine' moves the hearer from a position of 'Subject of Control' to 'Receiver of Grace'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'demand' of the cross is not a new Law (Devoir) but a necessary 'Performance' following the 'Competence' given by the Miracle.

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully avoids moralism by defining 'faith' not as a human work but as a 'dance' evoked by the 'inexplicable'.
